document.title: United States History I Content Standards

2B2DBB74618A47188E8F6EF1423B96B1.description:
Research primary sources such as antebellum newspapers, slave narratives, accounts of slave
auctions, and the Fugitive Slave Act, to analyze one of the following aspects of slave life and
resistance (e.g., the Stono Rebellion of 1739, the Haitian Revolution of 1791–1804, the
rebellion of Denmark Vesey of 1822, the rebellion of Nat Turner in 1831; the role of the
Underground Railroad; the development of ideas of racial superiority; the African American
Colonization Society movement to deport and resettle freed African Americans in a colony in
West Africa).

24A5EE488C904E09BE0736B8683B8967.description:
Describe the role of slavery in the economies of the industrialized North and the agricultural
South, explain reasons for the rapid growth of slavery in southern states, the Caribbean islands,
and South America after 1800, and analyze how banks, insurance companies, and other
institutions profited directly or indirectly from the slave trade and slave labor.

BA3A9DF45ACB4CFF957660A7A625265E.description:
Analyze the effects of industrial growth throughout antebellum America, and in New England, the
growth of the textile and machinery industries and maritime commerce.

22EDC2A7CFF44408B29BC98A6EE2EC4A.description:
Explain the importance of the Transportation Revolution of the 19th century (e.g., the introduction
of steamboats, canals, roads, bridges, turnpikes, and railroad networks; the completion of the First
Transcontinental Railroad and its stimulus to east/west trade, the growth of Midwestern towns
and cities, and the strengthening of a market economy).

53AD51B2585F42B591103A6FA8433013.description: Economic growth in the North, South, and West

F37D29AA6B004035A18C66422654FD28.description:
Analyze the causes and long and short term consequences of America’s westward expansion from
1800 to 1854

BD77BB5F8DD8476A9B040FFB51968A62.description:
Evaluate the presidency of Andrew Jackson, including the spoils system, the National Bank veto,
and the policy of Indian removal, and the Nullification Crisis.

71D1D136E77D4ABAAFABB7468F534FED.description:
Evaluate the major policies and political developments of the presidencies of George Washington,
John Adams, and Thomas Jefferson, and their implications for the expansion of Federal power and
foreign policy

5867D5B9F71C4A99BBD16B593305D2B5.description:
Describe the Constitutional Convention, the roles of specific individuals (e.g. Benjamin Franklin,
Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, George Washington, Roger Sherman, Edmund Randolph),
and the conflicts and compromises

EE2CC20BC6D641A4978304F1D8EEF80D.description:
Explain the reasons for the adoption of the Articles of Confederation in 1781 and evaluate the
weaknesses of the Articles as a plan for government, the reasons for their failure and how events
such as Shays’ Rebellion of 1786-1787 led to the Constitutional Convention

7E49113B5DE5472CAA1927B88D0FB91D.description:
Describe the key battles of the Revolution (e.g., Lexington, Concord, Bunker Hill, Trenton,
Saratoga, Yorktown); the winter encampment at Valley Forge; and key leaders and participants of
the Continental Army

8B02B1F7C1624A8E8E99D868BAB68904.description:
Explain the main argument of the Declaration of Independence, the rationale for seeking
independence, and its key ideas on equality, liberty, natural rights, and the rule of law.

D38FFC6AB09A40D2A4A87F8BB2E10AE8.description:
Describe Patriots’ responses to increased British taxation (e.g., the slogan, “no taxation without
representation,” the actions of the Stamp Act Congress, the Sons of Liberty, the Boston Tea Party,
the Suffolk Resolves) and the role of Massachusetts people

37F69554A19F48D8AFB0A6B0BAC3F014.description:
Explain Britain’s policies in the North American colonies (e.g., the Proclamation of 1763, the Sugar
Act, the Stamp Act, the Townsend Duties, the Tea Act, and the Intolerable Acts) and compare the
perspectives of the British Parliament, British colonists, and Native Peoples in North America on
these policies.

004E886B1A1343A688B2A22C04AEE0E4.description:
Explain the reasons for the French and Indian War (1754–1763), the North American component
of the global Seven Years’ War between Great Britain and France (1756–1763), and analyze how
the war affected colonists and Native Peoples

3B78EA595A6E49178C5F9D54F59F0FF7.description:
Analyze the economic, intellectual, and cultural forces that contributed to the American
Revolution.

40E589BBD50B4063B75C100EA75F8CCC.description: Origins of the Revolution and the Constitution
